when_to_say: Used when referring to the iconic river that flows through Paris.
example: La Seine traverse Paris. (sen) - The Seine flows through Paris.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing French geography or castles.
example: La Loire est connue pour ses châteaux. (lwar) - The Loire is known for its castles.

when_to_say: Used when discussing rivers in southeastern France.
example: Le Rhône se jette dans la Méditerranée. (rohn) - The Rhône flows into the Mediterranean.

when_to_say: Relevant in conversations about Bordeaux or southwestern France.
example: La Garonne traverse Bordeaux. (gah-ron) - The Garonne passes through Bordeaux.

when_to_say: Used when speaking about rivers ideal for canoeing.
example: La Dordogne est parfaite pour le canoë. (dor-do-nyuh) - The Dordogne is perfect for canoeing.

when_to_say: Used when discussing the Basque region or southwestern France.
example: L'Adour se jette dans l'Atlantique. (ah-door) - The Adour flows into the Atlantic.

when_to_say: Mentioned when talking about central France.
example: L'Allier est un affluent de la Loire. (ah-lyay) - The Allier is a tributary of the Loire.

when_to_say: Used when discussing the Champagne region.
example: La Marne est célèbre pour ses vignobles. (marn) - The Marne is famous for its vineyards.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing rivers in southwestern France.
example: Le Lot traverse Cahors. (lot) - The Lot passes through Cahors.

when_to_say: Used when discussing tributaries of the Loire.
example: La Vienne rejoint la Loire. (vyen) - The Vienne joins the Loire.

when_to_say: Used when talking about Burgundy or Lyon.
example: La Saône rencontre le Rhône à Lyon. (sohn) - The Saône meets the Rhône in Lyon.

when_to_say: Mentioned when talking about Cognac production.
example: La Charente est essentielle pour le Cognac. (sha-ront) - The Charente is essential for Cognac.

when_to_say: Used when speaking about rivers in southern France.
example: Le Tarn est connu pour ses gorges. (tarn) - The Tarn is famous for its gorges.

when_to_say: Used when discussing natural landmarks in France.
example: L'Ardèche est célèbre pour ses ponts naturels. (ar-desh) - The Ardèche is famous for its natural bridges.

when_to_say: Used when mentioning rivers in the Alps region.
example: L'Isère est un affluent du Rhône. (ee-zehr) - The Isère is a tributary of the Rhône.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing rivers in northern France.
example: L'Oise rejoint la Seine. (wahz) - The Oise joins the Seine.

when_to_say: Used when talking about rivers in Lorraine.
example: La Moselle est un affluent du Rhin. (moh-zell) - The Moselle is a tributary of the Rhine.

when_to_say: Used when discussing rivers in Normandy.
example: L'Orne se jette dans la Manche. (orn) - The Orne flows into the English Channel.

when_to_say: Used when discussing rivers in Languedoc.
example: L'Aude est connue pour ses vignobles. (od) - The Aude is known for its vineyards.

when_to_say: Used when discussing World War I history.
example: La Somme a été le site d'une bataille majeure. (som) - The Somme was a major battle site.

when_to_say: Used when talking about popular flowers or romantic gestures.
example: J'ai acheté une rose pour toi. (rohz) - I bought a rose for you.

when_to_say: Used when discussing spring flowers or gardens.
example: Les tulipes fleurissent au printemps. (tyu-leep) - Tulips bloom in spring.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing elegant flowers or symbols of purity.
example: Le lys est un symbole de royauté. (lees) - The lily is a symbol of royalty.

when_to_say: Used when talking about simple and cheerful flowers.
example: Les marguerites poussent dans les prés. (mar-guh-reet) - Daisies grow in meadows.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing exotic or delicate flowers.
example: L'orchidée est une fleur tropicale. (or-shee-day) - The orchid is a tropical flower.

when_to_say: Used when referring to small and fragrant flowers.
example: Les violettes fleurissent en hiver. (vee-oh-let) - Violets bloom in winter.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing bright yellow spring flowers.
example: Les narcisses annoncent le printemps. (nar-sees) - Daffodils announce spring.

when_to_say: Used when referring to wildflowers or remembrance symbols.
example: Les coquelicots recouvrent les champs. (koh-klee-koh) - Poppies cover the fields.

when_to_say: Used when talking about blue wildflowers.
example: Le bleuet pousse dans les champs de blé. (blu-ay) - The cornflower grows in wheat fields.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing lush and fragrant flowers.
example: Les pivoines fleurissent en été. (pee-vwan) - Peonies bloom in summer.

when_to_say: Used when discussing fragrant white flowers.
example: Le jasmin est utilisé en parfumerie. (zhahs-man) - Jasmine is used in perfumery.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing tropical flowers.
example: L'hibiscus est commun dans les îles. (ee-bees-kus) - Hibiscus is common in islands.

when_to_say: Used when discussing ornamental flowers.

when_to_say: Mentioned when talking about flowers for All Saints' Day.

when_to_say: Used when discussing fragrant spring flowers.
example: Les lilas parfument le jardin. (lee-lah) - Lilacs scent the garden.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing colorful wildflowers.
example: Les anémones se trouvent dans les bois. (ah-nay-mon) - Anemones are found in woods.

when_to_say: Used when discussing fragrant and colorful flowers.
example: Les freesias sont très parfumés. (fray-zee-ah) - Freesias are very fragrant.

when_to_say: Mentioned when talking about vibrant garden flowers.
example: Les azalées décorent les jardins au printemps. (ah-za-lay) - Azaleas decorate gardens in spring.

when_to_say: Used when referring to bright wildflowers.
example: Les renoncules poussent près des rivières. (ruh-non-kul) - Buttercups grow near rivers.

when_to_say: Used when discussing fragrant and relaxing plants.
example: La lavande est utilisée pour l'aromathérapie. (lah-vand) - Lavender is used for aromatherapy.

when_to_say: Used when referring to a common fruit or healthy eating.
example: J'ai mangé une pomme aujourd'hui. (pohm) - I ate an apple today.

when_to_say: Mentioned when talking about tropical fruits or snacks.
example: Les singes adorent les bananes. (ba-nan) - Monkeys love bananas.

when_to_say: Used when discussing citrus fruits or juice.
example: Je bois du jus d'orange le matin. (o-ranj) - I drink orange juice in the morning.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing sweet or seasonal fruits.
example: Les fraises sont mûres en été. (frez) - Strawberries are ripe in summer.

when_to_say: Used when talking about wine or vineyards.
example: Les raisins servent à faire du vin. (ray-zan) - Grapes are used to make wine.

when_to_say: Mentioned when talking about desserts or decorations.
example: J'adore la tarte aux cerises. (suh-rees) - I love cherry pie.

when_to_say: Used when talking about tart fruits or drinks.
example: Ajoute un peu de citron au thé. (see-trohn) - Add a bit of lemon to the tea.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing autumn fruits or desserts.
example: Une poire juteuse est délicieuse. (pwahr) - A juicy pear is delicious.

when_to_say: Used when discussing soft and sweet fruits.
example: Les pêches sont douces et juteuses. (pesh) - Peaches are sweet and juicy.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing exotic or tropical fruits.
example: La mangue est riche en vitamines. (mahng) - Mango is rich in vitamins.

when_to_say: Used when talking about refreshing summer fruits.
example: Le melon est parfait pour l'été. (meh-lohn) - Melon is perfect for summer.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing large and refreshing fruits.
example: Une pastèque fraîche est délicieuse. (pas-tehk) - A fresh watermelon is delicious.

when_to_say: Used when discussing Mediterranean fruits.
example: Les figues sont sucrées et tendres. (feeg) - Figs are sweet and tender.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing small stone fruits.
example: Les prunes sont mûres à l'automne. (pruhn) - Plums are ripe in autumn.

when_to_say: Used when discussing sweet summer fruits.
example: Les abricots sont riches en fibres. (ah-bree-koh) - Apricots are rich in fiber.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing small, tart berries.
example: Le cassis est utilisé dans les desserts. (kah-sees) - Blackcurrant is used in desserts.

when_to_say: Used when discussing berries or sweet treats.
example: J'aime la confiture de framboise. (fram-bwahz) - I love raspberry jam.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing wild or small berries.
example: Les myrtilles poussent dans les montagnes. (meer-tee) - Blueberries grow in the mountains.

when_to_say: Used when talking about exotic fruits.
example: Le kiwi est plein de vitamine C. (kee-wee) - Kiwi is full of vitamin C.

when_to_say: Used when discussing unique fruits or juices.
example: La grenade est riche en antioxydants. (gruh-nahd) - Pomegranate is rich in antioxidants.

when_to_say: Used when referring to a common pet or companion.
example: Mon chien s'appelle Max. (shyan) - My dog is named Max.

when_to_say: Mentioned when referring to a pet or feline animal.
example: Le chat dort sur le canapé. (sha) - The cat is sleeping on the sofa.

when_to_say: Used when talking about farm animals or equestrian sports.
example: Elle monte à cheval tous les week-ends. (shuh-val) - She rides a horse every weekend.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing flying animals or nature.
example: Un oiseau chante dans l'arbre. (wa-zo) - A bird is singing in the tree.

when_to_say: Used when discussing aquatic animals or seafood.
example: J'ai vu un poisson coloré dans l'aquarium. (pwa-sohn) - I saw a colorful fish in the aquarium.

when_to_say: Mentioned when talking about farm animals or dairy products.
example: La vache donne du lait. (vash) - The cow gives milk.

when_to_say: Used when discussing wool or livestock.
example: Les moutons broutent dans le champ. (moo-tohn) - The sheep are grazing in the field.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing farm animals or pork products.
example: Le cochon est sale, mais mignon. (koh-shohn) - The pig is dirty but cute.

when_to_say: Used when discussing pets or small mammals.
example: Le lapin mange des carottes. (lah-pahn) - The rabbit eats carrots.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing wildlife or cunning behavior.
example: Le renard chasse la nuit. (ruh-nar) - The fox hunts at night.

when_to_say: Used when discussing large wild animals or forests.
example: Un ours brun a été vu dans la montagne. (oors) - A brown bear was seen in the mountain.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing reptiles or dangerous animals.
example: Le serpent glisse silencieusement. (ser-pahn) - The snake slithers silently.

when_to_say: Used when talking about large animals or safaris.
example: L'éléphant a une trompe longue. (eh-lay-fahn) - The elephant has a long trunk.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing wild animals or bravery.
example: Le lion est le roi de la jungle. (lee-ohn) - The lion is the king of the jungle.

when_to_say: Used when discussing wild cats or powerful animals.
example: Le tigre chasse dans les forêts denses. (tee-gruh) - The tiger hunts in dense forests.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing tall animals or African wildlife.
example: La girafe mange des feuilles d'arbres. (zhee-raf) - The giraffe eats leaves from trees.

when_to_say: Used when discussing playful or intelligent animals.
example: Le singe grimpe aux arbres. (sahnzh) - The monkey climbs trees.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing marine mammals or intelligence.
example: Les dauphins nagent en groupe. (doh-fahn) - Dolphins swim in groups.

when_to_say: Used when discussing striped animals or African wildlife.
example: Le zèbre vit dans la savane. (zeh-bruh) - The zebra lives in the savanna.

when_to_say: Mentioned when discussing Australian wildlife or marsupials.
example: Le kangourou saute très haut. (kahn-goo-roo) - The kangaroo jumps very high.

when_to_say: Used when referring to the bird of prey, symbol of strength.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the large, flightless bird.

when_to_say: Used when referring to a type of hawk or buzzard.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the cuckoo bird, known for its call.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the domesticated bird, often associated with Thanksgiving.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the tall, pink wading bird.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the bird often seen by the sea.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the small migratory bird.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the colorful songbird.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the common bird known for its black plumage.
example: Le merle chante au matin. (The blackbird sings in the morning.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to the common bird found near the coast.
example: La mouette vole au-dessus des vagues. (The seagull flies over the waves.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to the bird known for its colorful tail.
example: Le paon déploie sa queue. (The peacock spreads its tail.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to the common bird found in cities.
example: Le pigeon se perche sur le toit. (The pigeon perches on the roof.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to small, colorful songbirds.

when_to_say: Used to refer to a small songbird.

when_to_say: Used to refer to a bird of prey known for scavenging.
example: Le vautour plane au-dessus des montagnes. (The vulture soars above the mountains.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to the capital city of France.
example: Paris est une ville magnifique. (Paris is a beautiful city.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to the city in eastern France, known for its cuisine and historical landmarks.
example: Lyon est célèbre pour ses bouchons. (Lyon is famous for its restaurants.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to the port city in southern France.
example: Marseille est située sur la Méditerranée. (Marseille is located on the Mediterranean.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to the city on the French Riviera, known for its beaches and cultural heritage.
example: Nice est une destination touristique populaire. (Nice is a popular tourist destination.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to the city in the southwest of France, known for its aerospace industry.
example: Toulouse est appelée la Ville Rose. (Toulouse is called the Pink City.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to the wine capital of France, located in the southwest.
example: Bordeaux est célèbre pour ses vins. (Bordeaux is famous for its wines.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to the city in northern France, close to the Belgian border.
example: Lille est une ville dynamique avec une riche histoire. (Lille is a dynamic city with a rich history.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to the city located in the Alsace region, known for its European institutions.
example: Strasbourg est célèbre pour sa cathédrale gothique. (Strasbourg is famous for its Gothic cathedral.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to a city located on the Loire River in western France.
example: Nantes est une ville portuaire historique. (Nantes is a historic port city.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to a city in the southern part of France, known for its universities and medical research.
example: Montpellier est une ville universitaire. (Montpellier is a university town.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to the city in Brittany, known for its historical buildings and festivals.
example: Rennes est une ville animée avec une grande culture bretonne. (Rennes is a lively city with a rich Breton culture.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to the city in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region, known for its thermal springs and festivals.
example: Aix-en-Provence est une ville pittoresque avec des marchés animés. (Aix-en-Provence is a picturesque town with lively markets.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to the city in southeastern France, famous for the Papal Palace.
example: Avignon est célèbre pour le Palais des Papes. (Avignon is famous for the Palace of the Popes.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to the city in northeastern France, known for its champagne production and cathedral.
example: Reims est la capitale du champagne. (Reims is the capital of Champagne.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to the coastal city in the Basque Country, famous for its surfing beaches.
example: Biarritz est une station balnéaire réputée. (Biarritz is a renowned seaside resort.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to a city in southern France, near the Spanish border.
example: Perpignan est une ville d'influence catalane. (Perpignan is a city with Catalan influence.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to a city in Normandy, known for its medieval history.
example: Caen est une ville historique avec un château médiéval. (Caen is a historic city with a medieval castle.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to the city in central France, known for its castles and Loire Valley wines.
example: Tours est au cœur de la vallée de la Loire. (Tours is at the heart of the Loire Valley.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to the city in eastern France, famous for mustard and Burgundy wine.
example: Dijon est célèbre pour sa moutarde. (Dijon is famous for its mustard.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to the city in the Rhône-Alpes region, known for its industrial history.
example: Saint-Étienne est une ville industrielle avec de nombreux musées. (Saint-Étienne is an industrial city with many museums.)

when_to_say: Used as a greeting during the day, particularly in the morning.
example: Bonjour, comment ça va ? (Hello, how are you?)

when_to_say: Used to say farewell or goodbye.
example: Au revoir, à demain ! (Goodbye, see you tomorrow!)

when_to_say: Used to make polite requests.
example: Pouvez-vous m'aider, s'il vous plaît ? (Can you help me, please?)

when_to_say: Used to express gratitude.
example: Merci beaucoup pour ton aide. (Thank you very much for your help.)

when_to_say: Used to apologize or get someone's attention.
example: Pardon, où est la gare ? (Excuse me, where is the train station?)

when_to_say: Used to congratulate someone.
example: Félicitations pour ton diplôme ! (Congratulations on your diploma!)

when_to_say: Used to wish someone a good meal.
example: Bon appétit ! (Enjoy your meal!)

when_to_say: Used to welcome someone.
example: Bienvenue chez nous ! (Welcome to our home!)

when_to say: Used to ask how someone is or to say that you're doing fine.
example: Ça va ? (How’s it going?) / Ça va bien, merci. (I’m doing well, thank you.)

when_to_say: Used when meeting someone for the first time.
example: Enchanté de faire votre connaissance. (Nice to meet you.)

when_to say: Used to express agreement or confirmation.
example: D'accord, je vais venir. (Okay, I will come.)

when_to_say: Used to politely interrupt or ask for forgiveness.
example: Excusez-moi, pouvez-vous m'aider ? (Excuse me, can you help me?)

when_to_say: Used as a polite response to 'thank you'.
example: Merci pour votre aide ! - Je vous en prie. (Thank you for your help! - You're welcome.)

when_to say: Used to praise or congratulate someone.
example: Bravo pour avoir réussi l'examen ! (Well done for passing the exam!)

when_to say: Used to say goodbye with the expectation of seeing the person again soon.
example: À bientôt, prends soin de toi. (See you soon, take care.)

when_to say: Used to wish someone good luck.
example: Bonne chance pour ton entretien ! (Good luck for your interview!)

when_to say: Used as a polite request or to invite someone to do something.
example: Je t'en prie, entre. (Please, come in.)

when_to say: Used to warn someone to be careful.
example: Faites attention à la route ! (Be careful on the road!)
Je suis désolé pour le retard. (I'm sorry for the delay.)

when_to_say: Use this word in arguments or fights when expressing 'stop' in French.
example: arrête! Je ne veux pas parler. (ah-ret) - stop! I don't want to talk.

example: non! Je ne veux pas parler. (nohn) - no! I don't want to talk.

example: tais-toi! Je ne veux pas parler. (teh-twah) - shut up! I don't want to talk.

when_to_say: Use this word in cricket commentary to refer to 'umpire' in French.
example: arbitre! Quel excellent jeu. (ar-beet-re) - umpire! What an excellent play.

when_to_say: Use this word in cricket commentary to refer to 'score' in French.
example: marque! Quel excellent jeu. (mark) - score! What an excellent play.

when_to_say: Use this word in cricket commentary to refer to 'six' in French.
example: six! Quel excellent jeu. (sees) - six! What an excellent play.

when_to_say: Use this word in cricket commentary to refer to 'four' in French.
example: quatre! Quel excellent jeu. (kat-re) - four! What an excellent play.

when_to_say: Use this word in cricket commentary to refer to 'defense' in French.
example: défense! Quel excellent jeu. (day-fahns) - defense! What an excellent play.

when_to_say: Use this word in cricket commentary to refer to 'attack' in French.
example: attaque! Quel excellent jeu. (ah-tak) - attack! What an excellent play.

when_to_say: Use this word in cricket commentary to refer to 'field' in French.
example: champ! Quel excellent jeu. (shom) - field! What an excellent play.

when_to_say: Use this word in cricket commentary to refer to 'fast' in French.
example: rapide! Quel excellent jeu. (rah-peed) - fast! What an excellent play.

when_to_say: Use this word in cricket commentary to refer to 'slow' in French.
example: lent! Quel excellent jeu. (lahn) - slow! What an excellent play.

when_to_say: Use this word in cricket commentary to refer to 'match' in French.
example: partie! Quel excellent jeu. (par-tee) - match! What an excellent play.

when_to_say: Use this word in cricket commentary to refer to 'victory' in French.
example: victoire! Quel excellent jeu. (veek-twar) - victory! What an excellent play.

when_to_say: Use this word in cricket commentary to refer to 'loss' in French.
example: perte! Quel excellent jeu. (pehrt) - loss! What an excellent play.

when_to_say: Used to express the concept or feeling of love.
example: L’amour est beau. (Love is beautiful.)

when_to_say: Used to refer to emotions, especially romantic ones.
example: Tu es dans mon cœur. (You are in my heart.)

when_to_say: Used to address a romantic partner affectionately.
example: Je t’aime, mon chéri. (I love you, my darling.)

when_to_say: Used when describing or expressing the act of kissing.
example: Je veux t’embrasser. (I want to kiss you.)

when_to_say: Used informally to refer to a kiss.
example: Un bisou pour toi. (A kiss for you.)

when_to_say: Used to express admiration or deep affection.
example: Je t’adore. (I adore you.)

when_to_say: Used to describe feelings, actions, or situations related to romance.
example: C’est si romantique ici. (It’s so romantic here.)

when_to_say: Used to express intense love or enthusiasm.
example: Notre amour est une passion. (Our love is a passion.)

when_to_say: Used to address a romantic partner lovingly.
example: Bonsoir, mon amour. (Good evening, my love.)

when_to_say: Used to compliment someone’s appearance, especially romantically.
example: Tu es belle ce soir. (You look beautiful tonight.)

when_to_say: Used to describe a person with whom one has a deep emotional connection.
example: Tu es mon âme sœur. (You are my soulmate.)

when_to_say: Used to describe the act of charming or attracting someone romantically.
example: Il sait comment séduire. (He knows how to seduce.)

when_to_say: Used to symbolize love or affection when given as a gift.
example: Une fleur pour toi. (A flower for you.)

when_to_say: Used to describe something subtle, fragile, or refined.
example: Ton parfum est délicat. (Your perfume is delicate.)

when_to_say: Used to describe feelings or moments that feel everlasting.
example: Notre amour est éternel. (Our love is eternal.)

when_to_say: Used to describe a more formal or literary kiss.
example: Un baiser doux. (A sweet kiss.)

when_to_say: Used to describe gentle or affectionate actions.
example: Un geste tendre. (A tender gesture.)

when_to_say: Used to describe commitments, especially romantic ones.
example: Une promesse d’amour. (A promise of love.)

when_to_say: Used to describe happiness, often related to love.
example: Ton sourire me donne de la joie. (Your smile gives me joy.)

when_to_say: Used to describe the art of attracting someone romantically.
example: La séduction est un art. (Seduction is an art.)

when_to_say: Used to express a sense of honor or satisfaction in achievements or identity.
example: J’ai une grande fierté pour ma culture. (I have great pride in my culture.)
